title: How 80,000 companies build with AI: Products as organisms and the death of org charts | Asha Sharma
themes: Future of work and team structures
key_insights: Products are evolving from static artifacts to living organisms that learn and improve through data feedback loops
Post-training is becoming more economically viable than pre-training once models hit 30 billion parameters
Organizations will shift from org charts to work charts as agents handle more tasks
Full-stack builders are having a renaissance as AI enables individuals to span multiple disciplines
Planning should focus on 'seasons' defined by secular changes rather than fixed timeframes
GUIs are shifting toward code-native interfaces as text streams connect better with LLMs
Successful AI companies embrace AI fluency across the organization before applying it to specific processes

guest_background.current_role: Chief Vice President of Product for Microsoft's AI platform

topics_discussed: Product as organism concept and metabolic product development
Agentic society and future organizational structures
Post-training vs pre-training economics and strategy
Planning strategies in rapidly changing AI landscape
15,000 customers building millions of agents on Azure
Full-stack builder emergence and role evolution
Reinforcement learning as critical product technique

memorable_quotes: We're approaching this world in which the marginal cost of the good output is approaching zero. We're going to see exponential demand for productivity and outputs.

All of a sudden, these are these living organisms that just get better with the more interactions that happen. I think this is the new IP of every single company products that think and live and learn.
I think it's all about the loop, not the lane here.
frameworks_mentioned: Product as organism vs artifact framework
Minimize regret vs maximize option value
summary: Asha Sharma shares unique insights on AI's transformation of product development, from static artifacts to living organisms, and predicts the emergence of an agentic society that will reshape organizational structures. She provides tactical guidance on post-training strategies, planning methodologies, and the evolution toward code-native interfaces while drawing from her experience overseeing Microsoft's AI platform serving 15,000 customers.
